Last night in class, we discussed the assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores the concept of "implacement" and the second, "displacement." Casey argues that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the primary situating force, with a focus on running out of time, saving time, and being just in time. He posits that centering culture around place can foster a more grounded community. So far, this book has been the most engaging read of the semester.

In the fall of 1974, I was attempting to struggle my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book for the 13th time. I am not, nor have I ever been, a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. So, as I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door, but no one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and, just as I was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that, my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door and, once again, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs, an uninvited practical joker.

Hands down, my go-to first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun rambos need not apply. Realistic recoil and ballistics are a must. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from a rifle caliber weapon can be fatal, unless it grazes you. Rounds drop in distance and short, controlled bursts are necessary to keep you on target. Halloween writer and producer Debra Hill, best known for her work on the 1978 horror classic Halloween, has died in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it grossed over $60 million worldwide, a record for an independent film at the time. Hill also worked with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way up to become an assistant director and second-unit director before collaborating with Carpenter. She was a pioneering woman in the film industry, taking on roles that were typically held by men in the 1970s.

Rosneft, a Russian state-owned oil company, has acquired Yukos' main oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas, for $9.4 billion in an auction that was disrupted by Yukos' bankruptcy filing in the US. Yukos had been fighting to avoid the forced sale of its assets, including Yuganskneftegas, to pay off a $27 billion tax bill. However, the company's efforts were unsuccessful, and the unit was sold to Rosneft.
Yukos' lawyers have now claimed that the auction violated US bankruptcy law, and the company and its main shareholders are vowing to go after any company that buys its assets, using all and every legal means. The acquisition of Yuganskneftegas by Rosneft is part of a larger effort by the Russian government to consolidate its control over the country's oil industry.

Voters flock to blog awards site for voting in the annual bloggies, recognizing the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts. According to Technorati, a blog search engine, there are around 6 million blogs, with over 12,000 new ones added daily. A new blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to US research think-tank Pew Internet & American Life, but less than 40% of blogs are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam builder defies Beijing, continues work on controversial dam despite government order. The China Three Gorges Project Corp. is refusing to stop construction on the Xiluodu Dam, despite a government order to do so, according to state-run media. The Xiluodu Dam is one of 30 large-scale construction projects that were called off due to a lack of proper environmental checks. The company may choose to pay a fine instead of complying with the order. The firm has also ignored orders to halt construction at two other projects - the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 targeted projects have complied with the shutdown order.

Manchester City 0-2 Manchester United: Red Devils' victory over Manchester City reduces Chelsea's lead in title race to nine points. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off Richard Dunne, to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient and they managed to fashion just one chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Anti-spam laws are biting spammers hard. The net's self-declared spam king, Scott Richter, is seeking bankruptcy protection. OptinRealBig, the company behind the spam, is fighting several legal battles, including one with Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. The company says filing for Chapter 11 will help it resolve its legal problems while continuing to trade. OptinRealBig was sued in December 2003 for sending spam messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who alleged that Richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.

Ireland surged past Scotland in their Six Nations match at Murrayfield, securing an impressive victory despite a strong challenge from the Scots. A third try from Wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended Ireland's lead. More women are taking charge of protecting their home computers against malicious net attacks, according to a two-year study by a net security firm. The number of women buying software to protect PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware rose by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study found that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired, with 53% of retired women buying security software compared to 46% of retired men. This reflects changing stereotypes and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the greater risks posed by high-speed broadband connections.

Scotland's Justice Minister, Cathy Jamieson, has warned bigoted soccer fans that she wants to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Roxy Music will headline the Wight Festival in June, along with Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. The festival takes place from June 10-12 and will feature original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzerana, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson taking to the stage on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is also working on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's "Virginia Plain," with other hits including "Street Life," "Love Is the Drug," and the 1981 John Lennon cover, "Jealous Guy.

Sideways dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six categories it was nominated for, including Best Film, Best Director, and Best Screenplay for Alexander Payne and writing partner Jim Taylor. The film also took home acting awards for Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. Sideways is expected to perform well at the Oscars, where it has five nominations. The Independent Spirit Awards, now in their 20th year, recognize films made outside the traditional studio system. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who won Best Actress for her role as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama Maria Full of Grace. Moreno is also nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars. Joshua Marston won the Best First Screenplay award for Maria Full of Grace.

Prince was named "top music earner" by US Magazine and Rolling Stone in 2004, beating Madonna and Elton John. He earned $56.5 million from concerts, album sales, and publishing deals with his Musicology tour and album. Madonna came in second with $54.9 million, while Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place with $24.9 million. Prince returned to the stage after a decade-long hiatus, with his tour taking in $90.3 million in ticket sales and selling 1.9 million copies of his latest album.

U2's Bono won the best international artist award at the NRJ Music Awards, beating out other international acts such as Ed Sheeran and Billie Eilish. In his acceptance speech, Bono thanked the fans in Japan for their support, saying, "I'm not from this country but I'll make a little confession to you - it's at the C√¥te d'Azur I feel at home." The international male and female prizes went to Shawn Mendes and Billie Eilish, respectively.

Tories unveil plans to give local communities the power to elect their own police commissioners, with the aim of increasing accountability and reducing crime. The new office would be created by scrapping the existing system of elected police authorities, which the Conservatives say is ineffective. The party's leader, Michael Howard, believes the new role would not supersede the job of a chief constable, but would instead provide an additional layer of accountability. The Liberal Democrats have criticized the plan, calling it "extravagant" and warning that it could allow extreme groups to dictate policing policies. The chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, Jan Berry, has also expressed concern, saying that the plan could result in those with extreme political views dictating what happens on the ground.

Paris promises to raise Welsh hopes as Wales faces a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? And can the Welsh revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? Those are the two questions occupying not just Welsh supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two of three Grand Slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades". Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games I have ever played in". A crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed: 'There was a French half... and there was a Welsh half.'

Doves have reached the top of the UK album chart with their new release, "Some Cities," replacing Flaming Lips at the summit. The band's single "Black and White Town" previously reached number six. R&B star Nelly has the number one single with "Over and Over," a collaboration with Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Usher also have new singles in the top ten, along with Futureheads and Kaiser Chiefs, who have their second chart hit with "Oh My God." Elvis Presley's latest re-release, "Marie's the Name," enters the chart at number three, just ahead of Girls Aloud's "Wake Me Up." Akon's "Locked Up" is at number five, while hotly-tipped Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs have their second chart hit with "Oh My God.

Davies favours Gloucester future, Wales hooker set to stay with English side despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but he would prefer to stay with Gloucester. Davies, one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is only on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proved his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to receive a new deal next season. The summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left Davies in the cold and forced him to take a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he gained match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, he admitted before his move to Gloucester that he was angry with the way he was treated.

Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin look to Africa for four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, who is ready to play in the Uefa Cup. Bnei Sakhnin is the first Arab side to compete in European competition and will face English Premier League side Newcastle United in the first round. Murambadoro, who made a name for himself at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, helped Bnei Sakhnin overcome Albania's Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro recently moved to Israel from South African club Hellenic. The club won the Israeli Cup final last season and are based in Sakhnin, which is near Haifa. The club has a strong ethos and is a high-profile promoter of peace and cooperation within Israel.

A new report suggests that cutting the drink-drive limit in the UK could save more lives than previously thought. Research from University College London claims that lowering the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg could save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill, which includes changes to speeding fines but not the drink-drive limit. The study, conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, also estimates that cutting the limit would lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the country's roads, saving the UK ¬£119m annually.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, providing a large detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. The proposed system measures pulse width, obviating the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC was fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process, consuming an average static power of 0.535 mW under 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system's functionality was successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

The text discusses the potential of optomechanics and electromechanics to create macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in compressed states, and in entangled states of motion. These advancements have enabled the idea of using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information, as well as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity prevents access to a broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy-squeezed states.
Early optomechanical proposals suggested the possibility of escaping this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. While there have been experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, these have not yet accessed non-classical states of motion.

Online reviews help customers make informed purchasing decisions. However, fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers can manipulate evaluations. These spammers have developed sophisticated strategies, adapting to evolving detection methods. Existing detectors prioritize accuracy, but this can undermine the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address this challenge, we formulate a game where spammers and detectors compete to achieve practical goals that are not solely based on accuracy. The Nash equilibria of this game lead to stable detectors that are resilient to mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. Using the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method, we derived a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, with solutions following a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Among this family, we identified a tracking solution with a single parameter to control fidelity, population of the excited state, and robustness. We defined a measure of robustness as the minimum percentile deviation on pulse areas at which infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. Our shaped pulses showed superior robustness compared to Gaussian and adiabatically optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we investigate the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to nonconvexity, there exist multiple local minima that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We show that all local minima share the same form of structure, which involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our results apply to the scenario where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition, and are valid even when the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain sharper results in terms of the scaling with the separation between the components.

We explore the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. The orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup $g$ of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface $x_m$ in weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. The first construction, Berglund-H\"ubsch-Krawitz (BHK), uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ inside it by a dual group $g^t$. In the second construction, Batyrev, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide simple evidence of the equivalence of these two constructions.

We present a novel mixed variable symplectic (mvs) integrator for planetary systems, which maintains stability during close encounters. The method combines a high-order mvs scheme with a time regularization technique to balance stability and accuracy. By reducing the effective step size during encounters, we can integrate over long timescales without sacrificing energy conservation. We demonstrate the algorithm's ability to resolve almost exact collisions while using the same time step as in weakly perturbed problems, such as the solar system. Our results show that the mvs algorithm outperforms hybrid methods like Mercury in terms of energy conservation over long timescales, making it a valuable tool for studying strongly perturbed planetary systems.

Entanglement is a key resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is entanglement witness, which measures the witness operator and guarantees a positive value for separable states and a negative value for certain entangled states. However, in reality, constructing an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states is challenging due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert space dimension with respect to the system size. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states requires only two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise.

In general relativity, the unique stationary solution is the Kerr spacetime with a distinct multipolar structure depending on mass and spin. We devise a method to extract multipole moments from arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a diverse family of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric, leading to a richer multipolar structure. This provides a means to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically, with numerical evidence suggesting larger multipole moments for a given mass and spin compared to the Kerr black hole. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment may offer only limited constraints on fuzzballs, while future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the Lisa mission will significantly improve these bounds.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibration of a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW) are reported. The PCW consists of two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between the beams. Models are developed and validated for the transduction of beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (GM) of the PCW for probe frequencies far from and near to the dielectric band edge. This research provides a foundation for evaluating possible deleterious effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of PCWs, with long-term goals of achieving strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the GMs of the PCW, thereby enabling opto-mechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.

This text describes a research paper that aims to investigate the impact of baryonic effects on the cosmic shear power spectrum, which is a key tool for studying the properties of the universe on large scales. The paper uses simulations to create a mock data set of the cosmic shear power spectrum and its covariance matrix, which are then corrected for baryonic effects following a baryonification method. The paper also develops an emulator to quickly predict the baryonic power suppression, allowing for a likelihood analysis of a standard $\lambda$CDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters. The main goal of the paper is to provide a better understanding of the uncertainties in the cosmic shear power spectrum due to baryonic effects, which is an important source of uncertainty for upcoming weak lensing surveys.

This paper proposes an open-source neural network model for classifying audio segments into different types of speech, including vocalizations produced by a child wearing a recording device, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. The authors gathered a diverse corpus of child-centered speech recordings, totaling 260 hours of recordings and covering 10 languages. The goal of the proposed model is to provide a tool for analyzing and understanding the quality and quantity of speech that children produce, as well as for early diagnosis and measuring the effectiveness of speech remediation. The authors propose a deep learning approach using a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural networks to classify the audio segments into the different speech categories.

The paper "Modal Clustering: A Nonparametric Density-Based Approach" by Z. D. B. Gao and J. A. D. C. G. G. T. Le, published in the Proceedings of the 21st ACM SIGKDD Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining, provides a novel approach to clustering data based on the concept of ideal population clustering. The authors propose a nonparametric density-based method, called modal clustering, which is motivated by the fact that the true density function is generally unknown and may have a complex structure.

The authors argue that the traditional parametric approach to clustering, which assumes a fixed density function, is not well-suited for dealing with the complexity of real-world data. Instead, they propose a nonparametric approach that models the density function as a function of the data distribution, allowing the algorithm to adapt to the underlying structure of the data.
The authors define the ideal population clustering problem as the partition of the data into groups such that the density of each group is as close as possible to the true density of the population. The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between standard model and higher-dimensional operators, which parameterize the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for the diboson scattering amplitudes suppress the na√Øve interference contributions of dimension six operators, causing the total diboson rate correction's leading contribution to cancel. In this case, measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, recouping sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail, and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by the construction of an asymmetry variable that is only generated by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can exhibit unconventional superconductivity at high critical temperatures is a major unsolved problem in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, but direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. We demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity, v$_{\rm c}$. We measure v$_{\rm c}$ as a function of interaction strength and find a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurement establishes ultracold fermi gases as a powerful tool for studying the impact of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

In this paper, we investigate the influence of chirality on the transport properties of a junction consisting of two WSM regions. We consider the case where the WSM regions are separated by a junction, and the junction direction is tilted with respect to the plane of the WSM regions. We study the differential conductance and pairing amplitudes of the junction as a function of the junction direction and the chirality imbalance between the WSM regions.

We find that the differential conductance and pairing amplitudes strongly depend on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the WSM nodes in momentum space. We identify the influence of a chiral chemical potential, i.e., the electron population imbalance between WSM nodes of opposite chirality, on the transport characteristics of the junction. Remarkably, we observe a net spin polarization of cooper pairs that are generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions. The spin polarization is opposite in the two WSM regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been shown to enhance electrical conductivity. This technique has been used in various applications, including grading voltage drops across high voltage insulators. It allows for increasing the maximum operational voltage without surface flashover. However, the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity is a concern, especially if the implanted metal species readily oxidizes. We investigated the long-term behavior of titanium-implanted alumina's surface conductivity. The results indicate a slow decrease of about 10% in conductivity over a year after an initial drop of around 40% in the first few weeks.

We propose a novel Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons based on the idea of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the Skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. In addition, singular configurations can be identified as baryon-charged under the new symmetry. Under this identification, vector mesons play the role of Chern-Simons vector fields on the quantum Hall droplet that forms the baryon. Our proposal provides a unified picture for the two types of baryons and allows them to continuously transform into each other in a natural way. Furthermore, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a result of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions combines anomalous Hall and Josephson physics in a single device. We theoretically investigate how this superposition impacts transport properties in superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. Transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling creates sizable transverse Hall supercurrents, which we refer to as anomalous Josephson hall effect currents. We generalize the Furusaki-Tsukada formula to evaluate transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes are adjustable by spin-orbit coupling strengths or superconducting phase difference across the junction. Well-localized subgap bound states form around the interface, providing a spectroscopic fingerprint of Josephson junctions.

Continuous-time quantum walks have proven a valuable tool for designing quantum algorithms. The quantum hitting time, or time to find a vertex of interest with high probability, is often used to characterize the running time. In this article, we improve upper bounds for the quantum hitting time, applying our techniques to the glued-trees problem and reducing the bound from $n^5$ to $n^2\log n$. Our methods also improve the dependence on precision for finding a marked node on an ergodic, reversible Markov chain, from $n^c$ to $n^c\log^c n$.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry or wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry EMRIs, previously thought to be the main source of EMRIs for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, are produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. We highlight an alternative EMI formation channel: wet EMI formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially moving on inclined orbits and drives them to migrate towards the MBH, boosting the EMI formation rate in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have no information about them, including no interaction with items, no user profile, and no social links with other users. Despite this lack of information, we still expect our recommender systems to attract the users at the first time and encourage them to stay on the website and become active users. This problem falls into the category of new user cold-start, which is crucial to the success and survival of a company. Existing approaches to user cold-start recommendation either require additional user effort, such as conducting an interview, or utilize side information, such as user demographics or social connections. However, users may not be willing to provide additional information, and side information is often not available for cold-start users.

Deep learning has surpassed heuristic algorithms in solving complex problems. Its application in wireless communications has also shown promising results, despite the well-established optimal algorithms for various tasks. While some gains have been achieved by learning individual parts of a receiver, a more effective approach is to jointly learn the entire receiver. However, this often translates to a challenging nonlinear problem, making it difficult to implement the optimal solution. To address this, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, Deeprx, that seamlessly integrates the entire receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5G-compliant manner. By carefully constructing the input of the convolutional neural network using both data and pilot symbols, we facilitate accurate channel estimation.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically uses an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) to generate new inputs by mutation. A corpus of potential seeds may contain thousands of similar inputs, leading to wasted effort. To address this, fuzzers use distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) to select the smallest subset of seeds that triggers the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. We present results of 34+ CPU-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches to understand their impact in finding bugs in real-world software.

In this paper, we explore the concept of multi-agent systems with partial observation, where multiple agents interact with each other and their environment without complete knowledge of the state of the other agents. We propose a new approach called a scalable supervisor, which is a template-based supervision mechanism that can handle multiple agents with different state transition structures. The scalable supervisor is designed to be efficient and scalable, meaning that its size and computational complexity do not increase significantly as the number of agents in the system grows.

We present a theoretical framework for synthesizing a scalable supervisor based on a given template, which is a high-level description of the system's behavior. The framework includes sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness, which ensure that the supervisor is both safe and flexible. We also provide an example of how the proposed approach can be applied to a simple multi-agent system.

Our main contribution is the introduction of a new notion of "partial observation," which allows us to relax the assumption of complete observability in traditional supervisory control. Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations are a valuable tool in multimedia forensics. Our proposed approach leverages temporal windowing and filter-bank capon spectral estimation to accurately estimate ENF. By using a type of Gohrberg-Semencul factorization and employing Krylov matrices for fast implementation, our method outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both power and speech recordings. With a short time window of 1 second, our approach achieves highly accurate results in terms of both time complexity and accuracy.

The direpack package aims to provide a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques as a single, consistent package in Python. The included methods fall into three categories: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. Additionally, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are provided, ranging from classical principal component regression to sparse partial robust M-regression. The package also includes a set of classical and robust pre-processing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Furthermore, direpack has been designed to be consistent with the scikit-learn API, allowing the estimators to seamlessly integrate into statistical and machine learning pipelines.

In this study, we demonstrated a new method for improving the spatial resolution of imaging in fluorescence microscopy. By using a differential excitation protocol, we were able to extract the high spatial frequency information of the fluorescence emission, which changed the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. This method has the potential to improve the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling with the defects in solids by approximately 1.6 times in comparison with confocal microscopy. The simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing also suggests that this method can be used for improving the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling with the defects in solids.

When random effects are correlated with survey design variables, traditional methods of estimating hyperparameters using inverse probability weighting no longer provide unbiased inference. We propose a weighted approach that achieves unbiased estimation for generating hyperparameters of random effects. In contrast to frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration, our Bayesian approach ensures both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. We demonstrate the utility of our method through simulations and a real-data example of a survey of business establishments, showcasing its versatility across different modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work bridges recent advances in combining traditional survey estimation methods with Bayesian modeling, providing a comprehensive framework for unbiased inference in survey analysis.

Low-symmetry 2D materials, such as res$_2$ and rese$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, and borophene, exhibit complex atomic structures compared to the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. These reduced symmetries lead to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as novel properties like ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. The "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic highlights recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials.

The relaxation of the electric birefringence of a melt in a mesogenic polymer can be described by a sum of several exponential processes, two of which play a decisive role. These main processes replace each other in a temperature range of about fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also made it possible to distinguish two processes of orientational relaxation: the first is due to rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second is associated with motion of the main chain segments.

This paper shows that the eccentric debris rings around stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than expected in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario, sometimes referred to as "pericenter glow." In this scenario, an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$ has its eccentricity increased to $e_f$ after the gas disc has dispersed due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width $2ae_f$. However, in a minor modification of this scenario, narrower belts can arise if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, which could result from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. Alternatively, a primordial eccentricity could be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity without the need for any planets.

Estimating the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a crucial step in many dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces intrinsic, an R package with novel state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators. The package includes three models: two-nn, gride, and hidalgo. These models are categorized into homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The former includes two methods (two-nn and gride) with inference under both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. The latter, hidalgo, is a Bayesian mixture model with an efficient Gibbs sampler. High-level, intuitive functions provide easy access to these novel estimators.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, promising to enable spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Two physical RC systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memory (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNO) were proposed and modeled to perform image classification and nonlinear dynamic system prediction tasks. Micromagnetic simulations revealed that a single MSM can achieve outstanding performance in handwritten digit recognition, while a physical RC system consisting of 24 STNOs can effectively solve complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems.

In this paper, we investigate the surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings in online platforms, where the fewer items in a given class, the higher their collective traffic share. This phenomenon, termed the "few-get-richer effect," emerges when people tend to click on top-ranked items and have heterogeneous preferences for different classes of items. We demonstrate analytically and experimentally how the strength of the effect varies with assumptions about the setting and human behavior. Our findings have important implications for understanding the spread of misinformation in online platforms.

Weight pruning has been widely recognized as a simple and effective method to reduce redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), leading to improved performance on various platforms. However, most pruning techniques come with a trade-off between model accuracy and regularity, resulting in impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration. To address this issue, we introduce a new sparsity dimension, pattern-based sparsity, which combines pattern and connectivity sparsity. Our approach consistently achieves accuracy enhancement and better feature extraction ability on various DNN structures and datasets, and our pattern-aware pruning framework achieves pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern pruning, and weight training simultaneously. Our approach naturally fits into compiler optimization for highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon. However, over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. Additionally, human activities, like burning fossil fuels, release some of that prehistoric carbon. Today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
